entry.content: Object-relational mapping, or ORM, is a technique that allows you to interact with databases using the object-oriented paradigm of the programming language of your choosing. How is that different from structured query language, though, and when do you use them?

entry.content: Posted by AJ Piergiovanni and Anelia Angelova, Research Scientists, Google Research While not immediately obvious, all of us experience the world in four dimensions (4D). For example, when walking or driving down the street we observe a stream of visual inputs, snapshots of the 3D world, which, when taken together in time, creates a 4D visual input. Today‚Äôs autonomous vehicles and robots are able to capture much of this information through various onboard sensing mechanisms, such as LiDAR and ca...

entry.content: Posted by Ali Kemal Sinop and Kostas Kollias, Research Scientists, Google Research In the world of networks, there are models that can explain observations across a diverse collection of applications. These include simple tasks such as computing the shortest path, which has obvious applications to routing networks but also applies in biology, e.g., where the slime mold Physarum is able to find shortest paths in mazes. entry.content: Posted by Daniel Suo, Software Engineer and Elad Hazan, Research Scientist, Google Research, on behalf of the Google AI Princeton Team Mechanical ventilators provide critical support for patients who have difficulty breathing or are unable to breathe on their own. They see frequent use in scenarios ranging from routine anesthesia, to neonatal intensive care and life support during the COVID-19 pandemic. A typical ventilator consists of a compressed air source, valves to control the flow of air i...

entry.summary: There's no free lunch in machine learning. So, determining which algorithm to use depends on many factors from the type of problem at hand to the type of output you are looking for. This guide offers ...
entry.content: There's no free lunch in machine learning. So, determining which algorithm to use depends on many factors from the type of problem at hand to the type of output you are looking for. This guide offers several considerations to review when exploring the right ML approach for your dataset.

entry.title: Building a Visual Search Engine ‚Äì Part 2: The Search Engine | KDnuggets
entry.summary: Ever wonder how Google or Bing finds similar images to your image? The algorithms for generating text based 10 blue-links are very different from finding visually similar or related images. In this ar...
entry.content: Ever wonder how Google or Bing finds similar images to your image? The algorithms for generating text based 10 blue-links are very different from finding visually similar or related images. In this article, we will explain one such method to build a visual search engine. We will use the Caltech 101 dataset which contains images of common objects used in daily life.
